message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of hyperglycemia and dehydration, indicating uncontrolled diabetes. The most appropriate next step in management is to start intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline and insulin to manage blood glucose levels. Option B is not appropriate as it contains only dextrose, which can worsen hyperglycemia. Option C can lead to hyperkalemia as the patient already has elevated potassium levels. Option D is not appropriate as it will only correct the acidosis and not the underlying hyperglycemia and dehydration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of hyperglycemia and acidosis, which indicate diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The most appropriate next step is to administer insulin to lower blood glucose and initiate intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline to correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Option B contains a solution with too much sugar for a patient with hyperglycemia, option C would not be appropriate without knowing the patient's potassium levels, and option D is not indicated in the treatment of DKA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis, which is confirmed by high glucose levels and positive ketones. The appropriate treatment is to hydrate the patient with normal saline and to administer insulin to lower glucose levels. Option (B) is incorrect as it contains too much glucose, which could worsen the patient's condition. Option (C) is incorrect as the patient's potassium levels are already high. Option (D) is unnecessary and not recommended for the treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high glucose level and ketonuria suggest diabetic ketoacidosis, and the appropriate treatment is intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline and insulin. Option B is incorrect because it does not address the high glucose level. Option C is incorrect because potassium chloride should not be given until serum potassium level is checked first. Option D is incorrect because it does not address the underlying cause of the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The initial treatment of DKA includes intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline and insulin to lower blood glucose levels and prevent further ketone production. Option B (intravenous hydration with 5% dextrose solution and 0.45% normal saline) is not appropriate because it may worsen hyperglycemia. Option C (intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline and potassium chloride) must be used with caution as potassium levels may already be elevated due to acidosis. Option D (intravenous sodium bicarbonate) is not recommended as it may worsen electrolyte imbalances and does not address the underlying cause of DKA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis, including increased thirst, weight loss, high glucose, and positive ketones. The blood gas also shows acidosis. The most appropriate next step is intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline and insulin, as insulin is needed to lower the high blood glucose and prevent further ketone formation. Potassium may also be added as needed to correct any electrolyte imbalances. Option B, 5% dextrose solution and 0.45% normal saline, would not adequately correct the high glucose and acidosis. Option C, 0.9% normal saline and potassium chloride, may be used if the patient has hypokalemia, but insulin is still needed to correct the underlying problem. Option D, intravenous sodium bicarbonate, may be used if there is severe acidosis, but insulin and hydration remain the primary treatments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis, which require immediate treatment with insulin and hydration with 0.9% normal saline. Option B, 5% dextrose solution, may worsen the hyperglycemia, and option C may worsen the hyperkalemia. Option D, sodium bicarbonate, is not necessary in the acute management of this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The most appropriate next step in management is intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline and insulin. This will help to replace fluids lost due to vomiting and increased urination, while also lowering the high glucose levels and correcting the acidosis with insulin. Option (B) does not provide enough electrolytes for the patient, (C) may worsen the already high potassium levels, and (D) is not recommended for DKA management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and the laboratory results confirm it. The next step in management should include intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline and insulin to correct hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. Option (B) is not recommended because 5% dextrose solution can worsen hyperglycemia. Option (C) is not recommended because hyperkalemia can occur in the recovery phase of DKA treatment. Option (D) is not recommended because intravenous sodium bicarbonate is used only in extreme cases of severe acidemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The initial management of DKA includes intravenous hydration with 0.9% normal saline and insulin to lower blood glucose levels and rehydrate the patient. Option B is incorrect because 5% dextrose solution will worsen hyperglycemia. Option C is incorrect because potassium replacement should be delayed until serum potassium levels are known, as insulin administration may cause rapid potassium shifts into the cells. Option D is incorrect as sodium bicarbonate is not indicated for DKA management.
